description: From Middle English salt, from Old English sealt, from Proto-West Germanic *salt, from Proto-Germanic *saltą, from Proto-Indo-European *séh₂ls (“salt”). Doublet of sal, ultimately from Latin sāl (“salt”), which it superseded as the general term for "salt".

adjectives.description: salt (comparative more salt, superlative most salt)

entries.meaning: Salty; salted.
Saline.
Related to salt deposits, excavation, processing or use.
examples: The salt factory is a key connecting element in the seawater infrastructure.

entries.meaning: (figurative, obsolete) Bitter; sharp; pungent.
(figurative, obsolete) Salacious; lecherous; lustful; (of animals) in heat.
examples: And when he saw that all the dogs were flocking about her, yarring at the retardment of their accesse to her, and every way keeping such a coyle with her, as they are wont to do about a proud or salt bitch, he forthwith departed  […]

entries.meaning: (colloquial, archaic) Costly; expensive.
A common substance, chemically consisting mainly of sodium chloride (NaCl), used extensively as a condiment and preservative.
examples: Soupes dorye. — Take gode almaunde mylke  […]  caste þher-to Safroun an Salt  […]

entries.meaning: (chemistry) One of the compounds formed from the reaction of an acid with a base, where a positive ion replaces a hydrogen of the acid.
(uncommon) A salt marsh, a saline marsh at the shore of a sea.
(slang) A sailor (also old salt).
(cryptography) Randomly chosen bytes added to a plaintext message prior to encrypting or hashing it, in order to render brute-force decryption more difficult.
A person who seeks employment at a company in order to (once employed by it) help unionize it.
(obsolete) Flavour; taste; seasoning.
(obsolete) Piquancy; wit; sense.
(obsolete) A dish for salt at table; a salt cellar.
examples: I out and bought some things; among others, a dozen of silver salts.

entries.meaning: (historical, in the plural) Epsom salts or other salt used as a medicine.
(figurative) Skepticism and common sense.
examples: Any politician's statements must be taken with a grain of salt, but his need to be taken with a whole shaker of salt.

entries.meaning: (Internet slang) Tears; indignation; outrage; arguing.
examples: There was so much salt in that thread about the poor casting decision.

entries.meaning: (UK, historical) The money demanded by Eton schoolboys during the montem.
One who joins a workplace for the purpose of unionizing it.

verbs.description: salt (third-person singular simple present salts, present participle salting, simple past and past participle salted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To add salt to.
examples: to salt fish, beef, or pork; to salt the city streets in the winter

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To deposit salt as a saline solution.
(nautical, of a ship) To fill with salt between the timbers and planks for the preservation of the timber.

definitionGroups.group: To insert or inject something into an object to give it properties it would not naturally have.

entries.meaning: (mining) To blast metal into (as a portion of a mine) in order to cause to appear to be a productive seam.
(archaeology) To add bogus evidence to an archaeological site.
(transitive) To add certain chemical elements to (a nuclear weapon) so that it generates more radiation.
examples: The composition of the fallout can also be changed by "salting" the weapon to be detonated. This consists in the inclusion of significant quantities of certain elements, possibly enriched in specific isotopes, for the purpose of producing induced radioactivity. There are several reasons why a weapon might be salted.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To sprinkle throughout.
examples: They salted the document with arcane language.

entries.meaning: (cryptography) To add filler bytes before encrypting, in order to make brute-force decryption more resource-intensive.
(military, transitive) To sow with salt (of land), symbolizing a curse on its re-inhabitation.
examples: In this place were put to the ground and salted the houses of José Mascarenhas.

entries.meaning: (wiki) To lock a page title so it cannot be created.
(obsolete) A bounding; a leaping; a prance.
examples: […] he hath the skill to drawTheir nectar forth, with kissing; and could makeMore wanton salts from this brave promontory,Down to this valley, than the nimble roe;
